text: this is Mikado Murphy for the New York
Times as an amusement park lover and
coaster enthusiasts I've spent several
summer weekends at parks around the
country searching for and writing some
of the tallest and craziest rides out
there but one thing I had not yet ridden
in all of my adventures a roller coaster
built into the side of a mountain the
coaster called boulder dash is at lake
compounce a family park in Bristol
Connecticut that's about a two-hour
drive from New York City I headed out to
lake compounce to see if boulder dash
was as cool as I expected a coaster
built into the side of a mountain might
be the coasters track zooms through the
woods and moves right alongside the
mountains rocky treeline terrain since
most of the track is hidden by trees the
only way to really understand where the
coaster is going is by writing it which
is exactly what I did with the first
drop of 115 feet and a large variety of
hills boulder dash looked like it could
be pretty exhilarating we weren't able
to record on the ride itself but the
park shared with us some video of the on
ride experience just to give you an idea
alright so i just finished driving
boulder dash it was pretty amazing I
really enjoy this part of the track that
you can kind of see is really a great
close very low to the ground which is
really different for wooden coaster but
it creates like this really kind of like
terrain hugging experience pretty
exciting to get a chance to ride it I'm
gonna go and check it out again
you
